channel.title: Pascal's Triangle
channel.description:
HEy i need help making a Pascal's Triangle in Word. This is the rubric: Start at column CV.
Pascal's Triangle is a discovery of the famous mathematician, Blaise Pascal. Once generated, it lends itself to any number of mathematical exercises. Your task will be to generate it.
Enter a value of 1 in the center column of the first row of the triangle. In all succeeding rows only formulas may be entered, no values. When you have finished, print and turn in a block, text and formulas, consisting of rows 93 through 100, columns 50 through 55.
The first five rows of pascal's Triangle look like this: 1 1 1 1 3 1 1 3 3 1 1 4 6 4 1

item.title: Pascal's Triangle
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

I know how to create excel macros. I also know enough VBA to say that the macro you posted simply takes a cell, changes its background color, and writes into it: “You are a cheese head”.

In java, the code would be:

final int NUMBER_OF_ROWS = 10;
 
for(int rowNum = 0; rowNum < NUMBER_OF_ROWS; rowNum++) {
   for(int columnNum = 0; columnNum <= rowNum; columnNum++) {
       System.out.print(solveBinomialCoefficient(rowNum, columnNum) +" ");
   }
   System.out.println();
}

Where the method solveBinomialCoefficient is:

public BigInteger solveBinomialCoefficient(int n, int k) {
    // Solves (n k) = n! / k!(n - k)!
    return factorial(n).divide(factorial(k).multiply(factorial(n - k)));
}
 
public BigInteger factorial(int n) {
    if(n == 0)
        return BigInteger.ONE;
 
    BigInteger factorialValue = BigInteger.ONE,
               iterationInteger = BigInteger.valueOf(n);
 
    while(iterationInteger.compareTo(BigInteger.ONE) > 0) {
        factorialValue = factorialValue.multiply(iterationInteger);
        iterationInteger = iterationInteger.subtract(BigInteger.ONE);
    }
    return factorialValue;
}

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @kloplop321 kloplop321
item.description:
@kloplop321 wrote:

my dad is “OK” at making excel macros, I will see if he could try.[br][size=1]Posted on: May 18, 2007, 04:37:31 AM[/size][hr]my dad made a simple excel macro this morning, he will bring back a book on it. But, in the current time, I don’t know if it would be due or not.

[php]
Sub Macro1()
’
’ Macro1 Macro
’
’ Keyboard Shortcut: Ctrl+a
’
Range(“B2”).Select
ActiveCell.FormulaR1C1 = “You are a cheese head”
Range(“B2”).Select
Columns(“B:B”).ColumnWidth = 20.71
With Selection.Interior
.Pattern = xlSolid
.PatternColorIndex = xlAutomatic
.Color = 65535
.TintAndShade = 0
.PatternTintAndShade = 0
End With
Range(“B5”).Select
End Sub
[/php]

item.title: Pascal's Triangle
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

To write a method for basic factorials, you can use a recursive function or a loop. With regular 32-bit integers, however, you can only calculate up to 12! iirc. Thus, for larger values you will need to use an arbitrary precision integer arithmetic library. For instance, Java gives you one in their standard API (with the BigInteger class). GNU GMP and NTL are some good C++ libraries.

By hand, it should be easy enough with that formula, yeah.

Read full topic

item.title: Pascal's Triangle
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

Factorials are used to describe binomial coefficients, which can be used to determine the integer sequences in Pascal’s Triangle. Its not really a proof, but a definition.

A single line in Pascal’s triangle can be determined with: (n k) where n is the column number and k is the row number. For a single row, obviously k is constant and n exists for 1 <= n <= k. Its difficult to express binomial coefficients here: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Binomial_coefficient - (n k) = n! / k!(n - k)!

Javacisnotrecognized pretty much already said that, though, and explained it more clearly for this question

Read full topic

item.title: Pascal's Triangle
item.dc:creator: @Javacisnotrecognized _^_
item.description:
@Javacisnotrecognized wrote:

Each number on the n’th row of the Pascal triangle are the same coefficients of a[sup]n-k[/sup] * b[sup]k[/sup] in the binomial expansion of (a + b)[sup]n[/sup] where k is the column.

In other words its (column! * (row - column)! ) / (row!) where ‘!’ is factorial. If you don’t know what factorial means, Google it.

Read full topic
